title: File from Path with Windows' invalid characters silently fails

labels.name: T-libs
labels.description: Relevant to the library team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
use std::path::PathBuf;
use std::fs::File;
use std::io::Write;

fn main() {
    let mut pb = PathBuf::new();
    pb.push("ok:err");
    pb.set_extension("ext");
    let mut file = File::create(pb).unwrap();
    file.write_all(b"test").unwrap();
    file.flush().unwrap();
}
```

I expected to see this happen: Since : is not allowed in filenames on windows I expected the filename to either be "okerr.ext" or at least "ok.ext". set_extension is a separate call and I would like it to be respected even if a previous push "failed". Expected a file with either of these names to be created and it's contents to be "test". Or, to receive an error if the write or flush fail.

Instead, this happened: A file named "ok" was created. It was empty even though neither of the unwraps failed.
